sp.l: Yes, and would you did so, where are your clothes?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Clothes! you see every woman almost go in her loose gown, and why should not we have our clothes lose?

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Would they were loose.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why where are they?

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: Where many a velvet cloak I warrant at this hour keeps them company, they are pawned to a broker.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why pawned, where's all the gold I left with you?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: The gold! we put that into a scrivener's hands, and he has cozened us.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: And therefore I prithee Angelo, if thou hast another purse, let it be confiscate, and brought to devastation.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Are you made all of lies? I know which way
Your gilt-winged pieces flew; I will no more
Be mocked by you: be sorry for your riots,
Tame your wild flesh by labour, eat the bread
Got with hard hands: let sorrow be your whip
To draw drops of repentance from your heart,
When I read this amendment in your eyes,
You shall not want, till then my pity dies.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: Is't not a shame that this scurvy puerilis should give us lessons?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: I have dwelled thou knowest a long time in the suburbs of the conscience, and they are ever bawdy, but now my heart shall take a house within the walls of honesty.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: O you drawers of wine, draw me no more to the bar of beggary; the sound of score a pottle of sack, is worse than the noise of a scolding oyster wench, or two cats incorporating.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: This must not be, I do not like when conscience
thaws, keep her frozen still: how now my masters?
Dejected, drooping, drowned in tears, clothes torn,
Lean, and ill coloured, sighing! what's the whirlwind
Which raiseth all these mischiefs? I have seen you
Drawn better on't. O! but a spirit told me
You both would come to this, when in you thrust
Yourselves into the service of that lady,
Who shortly now must die; where's now her praying
What good get you by wearing your our feet,
To run on scurvy errands to the poor,
And to bear money to a sort of rogues,
And lousy prisoners.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: A pox on 'em, I never prospered since I did it.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: Had I been a pagan still, I could not have spit white for want of drink, but come to any vintner now and bid him trust me, because I turned christian, and he cries puh,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You're rightly served; before that peevish lady
Had to do with you, women, wine, and money
Flowed in abundance with you, did it not?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Oh! those days, those days.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Beat not your breasts, tear not your hair in madness
Those days shall come again be ruled by me,
And better (Mark me) better.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: I have seen you sir as I take it, an attendant on the lord Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, yes, in show his servant, but hark hither.
Take heed nobody listens.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Not a mouse stirs.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I am a prince disguised.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Disguised! how! drunk,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes my fine boy, I'll drink to, and be drunk,
I am a prince, and anyaman by me
(Let him but keep my rules) shall soon grow rich,
Exceeding rich, most infinitely rich,
He that shall serve me, is not starved from pleasures
As other poor knaves are; no, take their fill,

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: But that sir, we are so ragged ...

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You'll say, you'd serve me.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Before any master under the zodiac.

sp.speaker: Harp.
sp.l: For clothes no matter; I have a mind to both.
And one thing I like in you, now that you see
The bonfire of your lady's state burned out,
You give it over, do you not?

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Let her be hanged.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: And poxed.

sp.speaker: Harp
sp.l: Why now you're mine.
Come let my bosom touch you.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: We have bugs sir.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: There's money, fetch your clothes home, there's for you

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Avoid vermin: give over our mistress! A man cannot prosper worse if he serve the devil.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: How? the devil! I'll tell you what now of the devil,
He's no such horrid creature, cloven footed,
Black, saucer-eyed, his nostrils breathing fire,
As these lying Christians make him.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: No!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: He's more loving,
To man, than man to man is.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Is he so! would we two might come acquainted with him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: You shall: he's a wondrous good fellow, loves a cup of wine, a whore, any thing, you have money, it's ten to one but I'll bring him to some tavern to you or other.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: I'll be the best room ith'; house for him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Some people he cannot endure.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: We'll give him no such cause.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: He hates a civil lawyer, as a soldier does peace?

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: How a commoner?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Loves him from the teeth outward.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: Pray my lord and prince, let me encounter you with one foolish question: does the devil eat any mace in's broth?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: Exceeding much, when his burning fever takes him, and then he has the knuckles of a bailiff boiled to his breakfast.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Then my lord, he loves a catchpole does he not? Har. As a bearward does a dog, a catchpole! he has sworn if ever he dies, to make a sergeant his heir, and a yeoman his overseer.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: How if he come to any great man's gate, will the porter let him come in sit?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: O, he loves porters of great men's gates, because they are ever so near the wicket.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Do not they whom he makes much on, for all his stroking their cheeks, lead hellish lives under him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.p: No, no, no, no, he will be damn before he hurts any man. Do but you (When you're thoroughly acquainted with him) ask for any thing, see if it does not come.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Anything!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Call for a delicate race whore; she's brought you.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: O my elbow itches: will the devil keep the door?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Be drunk as a beggar, he helps you home.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: O my fine devil! some watchman I warrant, I wonder who's his constable.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Will you swear, roar, swagger? he claps you.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: How! ath' chops.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, ath' shoulder, and cries oh my brave boy.
Will any of you kill a man?

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Yes, yes, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What's his word, hang, hang, 'tis nothing.
Or stab a woman.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Yes, yes, ay, I.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Here's the worst word he gives you, a pox on't go on.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: O inveigling rascal, I am ravished.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Go get your clothes, turn up your glass of youth,
And let the sands run merrily, nor do I care
From what a lavish hand your money flies,
So you give none away, feed beggars.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Hang 'em.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And to the scrubbing poor.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: I'll see 'em hanged first.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: One service you must do me.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Anything.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Your mistress Dorothea, ere she suffers,
Is to be put to tortures, have you hearts
To tear her into shrieks, to fetch her soul
up in the pangs of death, yet not to die.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Suppose this she, and that I had no hands, here's my teeth.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Suppose this she, and that I had no teeth, here's my nails.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: But will not you be there sir.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, not for hills of diamonds, the grand master
Who schools her in the Christian discipline,
Abhors my company; should I be there,
You'd think all hell broke loose, we shall so quarrel.
Ply you this business; he, her flesh who spares
Is lost, and in my love never more shares.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Here's a master you rogue.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Sure lie cannot choose but have a horrible number of servants.

div.head: Actus 4. Scaena 1.

sp.stage: A bed thrust out, Antioninus upon it sicks, with physicians about him, Sapritius and Macrinus.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: O you that are half gods, lengthen that life
Their deities lend us, turn o'er all the volumes
Of your mysterious Aesculapian science
T'encrease the number of this young man's days,
And for each minute of his time prolonged,
Your fee shall be a piece of Roman gold
With Caesar's stamp, such as he sends his captains
When in the wars they earn well: do but save him,
And as he is half myself, be you all mine.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: What art can do, we promise: physics hand
As apt is to destroy, as to preserve,
If heaven make not the medicine; all this while
Our skill hath combat held with his disease,
But 'tis so armed, and a deep melancholy
To be such in part with death, we are in fear
the grave must mock our labours.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I have been
His keeper in this sickness, with such eyes
As I have seen my mother watch o'er me,
And from that observation sure I find,
It is a mid wife must deliver him.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Is he with child, a mid wife:

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Yes, with child,
And will I fear lose life if by a woman
He is not brought to bed: stand by his pillow
Some little while and in his broken slumbers
Him shall you hear cry out on Dorothea,
And when his arms fly open to catch her,
Closing together, he falls fast asleep,
Pleased with embracings of her airy form;
Physicians but torment him, his disease
Laughs at their gibberish language, let him hear
The voice of Dorothea, nay but the name,
He starts up with high colour in his face,
She or none cures him, and how that can be,
(The Princess strict command, barring that happiness)
To me impossible seems.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: To me it shall not.
I'll be no subject to the greatest Caesar
Was ever crowned with laurel, rather than cease
To be a father.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Silence sit, he wakes.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Thou killest me Dorothea, o Dorothea.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: She's here; I enjoy her.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Where, why do you mock me,
Age on my head hath stuck no white hairs yet,
Yet I'm an old man, a fond doting fool
Upon a woman, I to buy her beauty,
(Truth I am bewitched) offer my life,
And she for my acquaintance hazards hers,
Yet for our equal sufferings, none holds out
A hand of pity.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Let him have some music.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Hell on your fiddling.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Take again your bed sir,
Sleep is a sovereign physic.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Take an ass's head sir,
Confusion on your fooleries, your charms,
Thou stinking glister-pipe, where's the god of rest,
Thy pills, and base apothecary drugs
Threatened to bring unto me, out you impostors,
Quacksaluing, cheating mountebanks, your skill
Is to make sound men sick, and sick men kill.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: O be yourself dear friend.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: Myself Macrunis
How can I be myself, when I am mangled
Into a thousand pieces, here moves my head,
But where's my heart? wherever , that lies dead.

sp.stage: Enter Sapritius dragging in Dorothea by the hair, Angelo attending.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Follow me thou damned sorcerers, call up thy spirits,
And if they can, now let 'em from my hand
Untwine these witching hairs.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I am that spirit,
Or if I be not (Were you not my father)
One made of iron should how that hand in pieces
That so defaces this sweet monument
Of my love's beauty?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Art thou sick?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: To death.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Wouldst thou recover?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Would I live in bliss?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: And do thine eyes shoot daggers at that man
That brings thee health?

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: It is not in the world?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Is't here?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O treasure, by enchantment locked
In caves as deep as hell, am I as near.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Break that enchanted caut, enter, and rifle
the spoils thy lust hunts after, I descend
To a base office, and become thy pandar
In bringing thee this proud thing, make her thy whore,
Thy health lies here if she deny to give it,
Force it, imagine thou assaultest a town,
Weak wall, to't, 'tis thine own, beat but this down,
Come, and unseen , be witness to this battery,
How the coy strumpet yields.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Shall the boy stay sir.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: No matter for the boy,
Pages are used to these odd bawdy
Shufflings, and indeed are those
Little young snakes in a fury's head
Will sting worse than the great ones,
Let the pimp stay.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O guard me angels,
What tragedy must begin now?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: When a tiger
Leaps into a timorous herd, with ravenous jaws
Being hunger-starved, what tragedy then begins?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Death I am happy so, you hitherto
Have still had goodness spared within your eyes,
Let not that orb be broken.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Fear not mistress,
If he dare offer violence, we two
Are strong enough for such a sickly man.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What is your horrid purpose sir, your eye
Bears danger in it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: I must.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: What.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Speak it out.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Climb that sweet virgin tree.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Plague a your trees.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: And pluck that fruit which none I think ever tasted:

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: A soldier, and stand fumbling so.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O kill me,Kneels.
And heaven will take it as a sacrifice,
But it you play the ravisher, there is
a hell to swallow you.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Let her swallow thee.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Rise for the Roman empire (Dorothea)
I would not wound thine honour, pleasure forced
Are unripe apples, sour, not worth the plucking,
Yet let me tell you, 'tis my father's will,
That I should seize upon you as my prey.
Which I abhor as much as the blackest sin
The villainy of man did ever act. Sapritius breaks in and Macrinus.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Die happy for this language.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Die a slave,
A blockish idiot.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: Dear sir, vex him not.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Yes, and vex thee too, both I think are geldings,
Cold, phlegmatic bastard, thou'rt no brat of mine,
One spark of me, when I had heat like thine
By this had made a bonfire: a tempting whore
(For whom thou'rt mad) thrust even into thine arms,
And standst thou puling? had a tailor seen her
Her at this advantage, he with his cross-capers
Had ruffled her by this, but thou shalt curse
Thy dalliance, and here before her eyes
Tear thy flesh in pieces, when a slave
In hot lust baths himself, and gluts those pleasures
Thy niceness durst not touch, call out a slave,
You captain of our guard, fetch a slave hither.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: What will you do dear sir.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Teach her a trade, which many would learn
In less than half an hour, to play the whore.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: A slave is to me, what now.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Thou hast bones and flesh
Enough to ply thy labour, from what country
Wert thou ta'en prisoner, here to be our slave.

sp.speaker: Slave.
sp.l: From Britain.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: In the West ocean.

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: An island.

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: I am fitted, of all nations
Our Roman swords ever conquered, none comes near
The Britain for true whoring: sirrah fellow,
What wouldst thou do to gain thy liberty?

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.l: Do! liberty! fight naked with a lion,
Venture to pluck a standard from the heart
Of an armed legion: liberty! I'd thus
Bestride a rampire, and defiance spit
I'th face of death; then, when the battering ram
Were fetching his career backward to pash
Me with his horns in pieces: to shake my chains off,
And that I could not do't but by thy death,
Stoodst thou on this dry shore, I on a rock
Ten pyramids high, down would I leap to kill thee,
Or die myself: what is for man to do
I'll venture on, to be no more a slave.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Thou shalt then be no slave, for I will set thee
Upon a piece of work is fit for man,
Brave for a Britain, drag that thing aside
And ravish her.

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.l: And ravish her! is this your manly service,
A devil scorns to do't, 'tis for a beast,
A villain, not a man, I am as yet
But half a slave, but when that work is past,
A damned whole one, a black ugly slave,
The slave of all base slaves, do't thyself roman,
'Tis drudgery fit for thee.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: He's bewitched too,
Bind him, and with a bastinado give him
Upon his naked belly 200. blows.

sp.speaker: Slave
sp.l: Thou art more slave than I.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: That power supernal on whom waits my soul,
Is captain o'er my chastity.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Good sir give o'er,
The more you wrong her, yourselves vexed the more,

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Plague's light on her and thee; thus down I throw
thy harlot thus byth' hair, nail her to earth,
Call in ten slaves, let every one discover
What lust desires, and surfeit here his fill,
Call in ten slaves.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: They are come sir at your call.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: O o. Falls down.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Where is the governor?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: There's my wretched father.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My lord, Sapritius, he's not dead, my lord,
That witch there.

sp.speaker: Aut.
sp.l: 'Tis no Roman gods can strike
These fearful terrors, oh thou happy maid,
Forgive this wicked purpose of my father.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I do.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Gone, gone, he's peppered: 'tis thou
Hast done this act internal.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Heaven pardon you,
And if my wrongs from thence pull vengeance down
(I can no miracles work) yet from my soul
Pray to those powers I serve, he may recover.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: He stirs, help, raise him up, my lord.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: The
sp.l: One cheek is blasted.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Blasted! Where's the Lamia
That tears my entrails? I'm be witched, seize on her?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: I'm here, do what you please.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Spurn her to th' bar.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Come boy, being there, more near to heaven we are

sp.speaker: Sap
sp.l: Kick harder, go out witch.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: O bloody hangmen, thine own gods give thee breath,
Each of thy tortures is my several death.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Do you like my service now, say am not I
A master worth attendance.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p:
Attendance, I had rather lick clean the soles of
your dirty boots, then wear the richest suit of any infected lord, whose rotten life hangs between the 2 poles.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: A lords suit! I would not give up the cloak of your service to meet the splay-foot estate of any left-eyed knight above the antipodes, because they are unlucky to meet.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: This day I'll try your loves to me, 'tis only
But well to use the agility of your arms,

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Or legs, I am lofty at them.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Or any other member that has no legs.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Thou'lt run into some hole.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: If I meet one that's more than my match, and that I cannot stand in their hands, I must and will creep on my knees.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Hear me my little team of villains, hear me,
I cannot teach you fencing with these cudgels,
Yet you must use them, lay them on but soundly,
That's all.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Nay if we come to malling once, puh,

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: But what walnut tree is it we must beat.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Your mistress.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: How! my mistress! I begin to have a Christians heart, made of sweet butter, I melt, I cannot strike a woman.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Not I, unless she scratch, bum my mistress!

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: You're coxcombs, silly animals,

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Drones, asses, blinded moles, that dare not thrust
Your arms out to catch fortune, say you fall off,
It must be done you are converted rascals,
And that once spread abroad, why every slave
Will kick you, call you motley Christians,
And half faced Christians.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: The guts of my conscience begin to be of whitleather,

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: I doubt me I shall have no sweet butter in me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Deny this, and each pagan whom you meet
Shall forked fingers thrust into your eyes.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: If we be cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Do this, and every god the gentiles bow to,
Shall add a fathom to your line of years.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: A hundred fathom, I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: I desire but one inch longer,

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: The senators will as you pass along
Clap you upon your shoulders with this hand,
And with this hand glue you gold when you are dead,
Happy that man shall be can get a nail,
The paring —, they the dirt under the nail
Of any of you both, to say this dirt
Belonged to Spungius or Hercius.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: They shall not want dirt under my nails, I'll keep 'em long of purpose, for now my singer's itch to be at her.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: The first thing I do I'll take her o'er the lips.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: And I the hips, we may strike anywhere .

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Yes, anywhere .

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: Then I know where I'll hit her.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Prosper and be mine own; stand by, I must not
To see this done, great business calls me hence,
He's made can make her curse his violence.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Fear it not sir, her ribs shall be basted.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: He come upon her with rounce, robble-hobble, and thwick-thwack thirlety bouncing.

sp.stage: Enter Dorothea lead prisoner, a guard attending, a hangman with cords in some ugly shape, sets up a pillar in the middle of the stage, Sapritius and Theophilus sit, Angelo by her.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: According to our Roman customs, bind
That christian to a pillar.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Infernal furies,
Could they into my hand thrust all their whips
To tear thy flesh thy soul, 'tis not a torture
Fit to the vengeance, I should heap on thee,
For wrongs done me: me! for flagitious facts
By thee done to our gods, yet (So it stand
To great Caesarea's governors high pleasure)
Bow but thy knee to Jupiter and offer
Any slight sacrifice, or do but swear
by Caesar's fortune, and be free.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Not for all Caesar fortune, were it chained
To more worlds, then are kingdoms in the world,
And all those worlds drawn after him: I defy
Your hangmen; you now show me whither to fly.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Are her tormentors ready?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Shrink not dear mistress.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: My lord, we are ready for the business.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: You two! whom I like fostered children fed,
And lengthened out your starved life with bread:
You be my hangman! whom when up the ladder
Death hauled you to be strangled, I fetched down
Clothed you, and warmed you, you two my tormentors.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Yes, use.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Divine powers pardon you.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Strike.Strike at her: Angelo kneeling holds her fast.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Beat out her brains —,

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Receive me you bright angels.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Faster slaves.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: Faster: I am out of breath I'm sure: if I were to beat a buck, I can strike no harder.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: O mine arms, I cannot list 'em to my head.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Joy above joys, are my tormentors weary
In torturing me, and in my sufferings
I fainting in no limb: ●●●●anto strike home
And feast your fury full.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: These dogs are ours.Come from his seat.
Which snarl, yet bite not: see my lord, her face
Has more bewitching beauty then before,
Proud whore: it smiles, cannot an eye shart out
With these.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: No sir, not the bridge of her nose fall, 'tis full of iron work.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Let's view the oudgols, are they not counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: There fix thine eye still, thy glorious crown must come
Not from soft pleasure, but by martyrdom,
There fix thine eye still, when we next do meet,
not thorns, but roses shall bear up thy feet:
There fix thine eye still.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Ever, ever, ever.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.p: We are mocked, these bats have power down to fell giants, yether skin is not feared.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: What rogues are these.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Cannot these force a shriek.Beats them.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: Oh! a woman has one of my ribs, and now five more are broken.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Cannot this make her roar.Beats tother he roars

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.l: Who hired these slaves? what are they?

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: We serve that noble gentleman there, he enticed us to this dry-beating, o for one half pot.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: My servants! two base rogues, and sometimes servants
To her and for that cause forbear to hurt her.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Unbind her, hang up these.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Hang the two hounds on the next tree.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Hang us! master Harpax, what a devil shall we be thus used.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: What bandogs but you two would worry a woman!
Your mistessell but clapped you, you flew on:
Say I should get your lives, each rascal beggar
Would when he met you, cry, out hellhounds, traitors
Spit at you, fling dirt at you, and no woman
Ever endure your fight: 'tis your best course
(Now had you secret knives) to stab yourselves,
But since you have not, go and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I is your best course.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Why stay they trifling here?
To gallows drag 'em by the heels: away.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.p: By the heels! no sir, we have legs to do us that service.

sp.speaker: Hir.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if no woman can endure my sight, away with me.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Dispatch 'em.

sp.speaker: Spun.
sp.l: The devil dispatch thee.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Death this day ride in triumph, Theophilus.
See this witch made away to.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: My soul thirst for it,
Come, I myself, thy hangman's part could play.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: O hasten me to my coronation day.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Is this the place where virtue is to suffer,
And heavenly beauty leaving this base earth,
To make a glad return from whence it came,
Is it Macrinus? A scaffold thrust forth

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: By this preparation
You well may rest assured that Dorothea
This hour is to die here.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Then with her dies
The abstract of all sweetness that's in woman,
Set me down friend, that ere the iron hand
Of death close up mine eyes, they may at once
Take my last leave both of this light, and her:
For she being gone, the glorious sun himself
To me's Cimmerian darkness.

sp.speaker: Macr.
sp.l: Strange affection!
Cupid once more hath changed his shafts with death,
And kills in stead of giving life.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Nay weep not,
Though tears of friendship be a sovereign balm,
On me they are cast a way: it is decreed
That I must die with her, our clew of life
Was spun together.

sp.speaker: Macr.
sp.l: Yet sir 'tis my wonder
That you who hearing only what she suffers,
Partake of all her tortures, yet will be
To add to your calamity, an eye witness
Of her last tragic scene, which must pierce deeper
And make the wound more desperate.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: O Macrinus,
'Twould linger out my torment self, not kill me,
which is the end I aim at, being to die to.
What instrument more glorious can I wish for,
Then what is made sharp by my constant love
And true affection. It may be the duty
And loyal service with which I pursued her,
And sealed it with my death, will be remembered
Among her blessed actions, and what honour
Can I desire beyond it?
sp.stage: Enter a guard bringing in Dorothea, a headsman before her, followed by Theophitus, Sapritius, Harpax.
sp.l: See she comes,
How sweet her innocence appears, more like
To heaven itself then any sacrifice
That can be offered to it. By my hopes
Of joys hereafter, the sight makes me doubtful
In my belief, nor can I think our gods
Are good, or to be served, that take delight
In offerings of this kind, that to maintain
Their power, do face the master piece of nature,
Which they themselves come short of she ascends,
An every step raises her nearer heaven.
What god soe'er thou art that most enjoy her,
Receive in her a boundless happiness

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: You are too blame
To let him come abroad.

sp.speaker: Macr.
sp.l: It was his will,
And we were left to serve him, not command him,

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Good sir be not offended, nor deny
My last of pleasures in this happy object
That I shall ere be blessed with.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Now proud contemner
Of us and of our gods, tremble to think
It is not in the power thou servest, to save thee.
Not all the riches of the sea increased
By violent shipwracks, nor the unsearched mines
Mammon's unknown exchequer shall redeem thee.
And therefore having first with horror weighed
What 'tis to die, and to die young, to part with
All pleasures, and delights: lastly, to go
Where all antipathies to comfort dwell
Furies behind, about thee, and before thee,
And to add to affliction the remembrance
Of the Elysian joys thou mightst have tasted,
Hadst thou not turned apostata to those gods
That so reward their servants, let despair
Prevent the hangman's sword, and on this scaffold
Make thy first entrance into hell.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: She smiles,
Unmoved by Mars, as if she were assured
Death looking on her constancy would forget
The use of his inevitable hand.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Derided to? dispatch I say.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Thou fool
That gloriest in having power to ravish
A trifle from me I am weary of:
What is this life? to me not worth a thought
Or if to be esteemed, 'tis that I lose it
To win a better, e'en thy realice serves
To me but as a ladder to mount up
To such a height of happiness where I shall
Look down with scorn on thee, and on the world,
Where circled with true pleasures, placed above
The reach of death or time, 'twill be my glory
To think at what an, easy price I bought it.
There's a perpetual spring, perpetual youth,
No joint benumbing cold, nor scorching heat,
Famine nor age have any being there:
Forget for shame your Tempe, bury in
Oblivion, your feigned your Hesperian orchards
The golden fruit kept by the watchful dragon
Which did require Hercules to get it
Compared with what grows in all plenty there,
Deserves not to be named. The power I serve
Laughs at your happy Arabia, or the
Elysian shades, for he hath made his bowers
Better indeed than you can fancy yours.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: O take me thither with you.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Trace my steps
And be assured you shall.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: With mine own hands
He rather stop that little breath is left thee,
And rob thy killing fever.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By no means,
Let him go with her, do seduced young man,
And wait upon thy saint in death, do, do,
And when you come to that imagined place,
That place of all delights, pray you observe me,
And meet those cursed things I once called daughters,
Whom I have sent as harbingers before you,
If there be any truth in your religion,
In thankfulness to me that with care hasten
Your journey thither, pray send me some
Small pittance of that curious fruit you boast of.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.l: Grant that I may go with her, and I will.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Wilt thou in thy last minute dam thyself?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: The gates to hell are open.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.l: Know thou tyrant
Thou agent for the devil thy great master
Though thou art most unworthy to taste of it,
I can and will.
sp.stage: Enter Angelo in the angel's habit.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Oh! mountains fall upon me,
Or hide me in the bottom of the deep,
Where light may never find me.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: This is prodigious, and confirms her witch craft.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Harpax my Harpax speak.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I dare not stay,
Should I but hear her once more I were lost,
Some whirl wind snatch me from this cursed place,
To which compared (And with what now I suffer)
Hell's torments are sweet slumbers.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Follow him.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: He is distracted, and I must not lose him,
Thy charms upon my servant cursed witch,
Gives thee a short reprieve, let not her die
Till my return.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: She minds him not, what object
Is her eye fixed on?

sp.speaker: Macr.
sp.l: I see nothing.

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Mark her.

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: Thou glorious minister of the power I serve,
For thou art more than mortal, is't for me
Poor sinner, thou art pleased a while to leave
Thy heavenly habitation? and vouchsafest
Though glorified, to take my servant's habit,
For put off thy divinity, so looked
My lovely Angelo.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Know I am the same,
And still the servant to your piety,
Your zealous prayers and pious deeds first won me
(But 'twas by his command to whom you sent 'em)
To guide your steps. I tried your charity,
When in a beggar's shape you took me up
And clothed my naked limbs, and after fed
(As you believed) my famished mouth. Learn all
By your example to look on the poor
With gentle eyes, for in such habits often
Angels desire an alms. I never left you,
Nor will I now, for I am sent to carry
Your pure and innocent soul to joys eternal,
Your martyrdom once suffered, and before it
Ask any thing from me, and rest assured
You shall obtain it

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: I am largely paid
For all my torments, since I find such grace
Grant that the love of this young man to me,
In which he languisheth to death, may be
Changed to the love of heaven,

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: I will perform it.
And in that instant when the sword saeta free
Your happy soul his shall have liberty.
Is there ought else?

sp.speaker: Doro.
sp.l: For proof that I forgive
My 〈◊〉, who in scorned desired
To taste of that most 〈◊〉 fruit I go to
After my death as sent from me, be pleased
To give him of it.

sp.speaker: Ange.
sp.l: Willingly dear mistress.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I am amazed

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: I feels a holy fire
That yields a comfortable heat within me.
I am quite altered from the thing I was.
See I can stand, and go alone, thus kneels
To heavenly Dorothea, touch her hand
With a religious kiss.

sp.speaker: Sapr.
sp.l: He is well now,
But will not be drawn 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: It matters not,
We can discharge this works without his help:
But see your son. Sapr, villain

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: Sir I be you,
Being so near our ends divorce us not.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: He quickly make a separation of .
Hast thou ought else to say?

sp.speaker: Dorothea.
sp.l: Nothing but blame
Thy tardiness in sending me to rest,
My peace is made with heaven, to which my soul
Begins to take her flight, strike, o. strike quickly,
And though you are un moved to be my death
Hereafter when my story shall be read,
As they were present now, the hearers shall
Say this of Dorothea with wet eyes
She lived a virgin, and a virgin dies.Her head struck off

sp.speaker: Anton.
sp.l: O take my soul along to wait on mine.

sp.speaker: Macr.
sp.l: Your son sinks to. Antonius sinks

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Already dead.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Die all.
That are or favour this accursed sect,
I triumph in their ends, and will raise up
A hill of their dead carcases, to or cloak
The pyrenean hills, but I'll root out.
These superstitious fools, and leave the world
No name of christian.

sp.stage: Loud music, exit Angelo leaving first laid his hand up. on their mouths.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Ha, heavenly music.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: 'Tis in the air.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Illusions of the devil
Wrought by some one of her religion.
That fain would make her death a miracle,
It frights not me: because he is your son
Let him have burial, but let her body
Be cast forth with contempt in some high way,
And be to vultures and to dogs a prey.

div.trailer: The end of the fourth act.

sp.stage: Enter Theophilus in his study, books about him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Is't holiday (O Caesar) that thy servant,
(Thy Provost, to see execution done
On these base Christians in Caesarea)
Should now want work: sheep these idolaters
That none are stirring, as a curious painterRises.
When he has made some admirable piece,
Stands off, and with a searching eye examines
Each colours how 'tis sweetened, and then hugs
Himself for his rare workmanship. — so hereSits.
Will I my drolleries and bloody lantskips
Long passed wrapped up unfold to make me merry
With shadows, now I want the substances. Books.
My muster-book of hellhounds, were the Christians
Whose names stand here (Alive) and armed, not Rome
Could move upon her hinges. What I have done,
Or shall hereafter, is not out of hate
To poor tormented wretches, no I am carried
with violence of zeal, and streams of service
I owe our Roman gods. Great Britain, what.
A thousand wives with brats sucking their breasts,
Had hot irons pinch 'em off and thrown to swine;
And then their fleshy backparts he wed with hatchets,
Were mined and baked in pies to feed starved Christians. Ha, ha.
Again, again, — East. Anglas —, o, East-angles,
Bandogs (Kept three days hungry) worried
1000. British rascals, stied up, fat
Of purpose, striped naked, and disarmed.
I could outstare a year of suns and moons,
To sit at these sweet bul-baitings, so I could
Thereby but one christian win to fall
In adoration to my Jupiter. Twelve hundred
Eyes bored with augurs out: o! eleven thousand
Torn by wild beasts: two hundred rammed i'th earth
To'th armpits, and full platters round about 'em,
But far enough for reaching, eat dogs, ha, ha, ha.
Tush, all these tortures are but phillipings,
Flea-bitings; I before the destinies
My bottom did wind up, would flesh myself
Once more, upon some one remarkable
Above all these, this Christian slut was well,
A pretty one, but let such horror follow
The next I feed with torments, that when Rome
Shall hear it, her foundation at the sound
May feel an earthquake. How now? Music.
sp.stage: Rise consort, enter Angelo with a basket filled with fruit and flowers.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Are you amazed sir — so great a Roman spirit and does it tremble.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: How cam'st thou in? to whom thy business?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: To you:
I had a mistress late sithence by you
Upon a bloody errand, you entreated
That when she came into that blessed garden
Whither she knew she went, and where (Now happy)
She feeds upon all joy, she would send to you
Some of that garden fruit and flowers, which here
to have her promise saved, are brought by me.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Cannot I see this garden?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yes, if the master
Will give you entrance. Angelo vanisheth.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis attempting fruit, and the most bright checked child I ever viewed,
Sweet smelling goodly fruit, what flowers are these?
In Dioclesian's gardens, the most beauteous
Compared with these are weeds: is it not February?
The second day she died: frost, ice and snow
Hang on the beard of winter, where's the sun
That guilds this summer, pretty sweet boy, say in what country
Shall a man find this garden —, my delicate boy, gone! Vanished!
Within there, juliarues and Gota. —

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: My lord.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Are my gates shut?
And guarded.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Saw you not — a boy.
Where?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Here he entered, a young lad, 1000. blessings danced upon his eyes, a smooth faced glorious thing, that brought this basket.

sp.l: No sir?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Away, but be in reach if my voice calls you,
No! vanished! and not seen, be thou a spirit
Sent from that witch to mock me, I am sure
This is essential, and howe'er it grows,
Will taste it.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha. Harpax within.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: So good, I'll have some now sure.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, great liquorish fool.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: A fisherman,

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What dost thou catch;

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Souls, souls, a fish called souls.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Geta.
My lord.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha. Within.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What insolent slave is this dares laugh at me?
Or what is't the dog grins at so?

sp.p: I neither know my lord at what, nor whom, for there is none without but my fellow Julianus, and he's making a garland for Jupiter.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Jupiter! all within me is not well,
And yet not sick.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha.Louder.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What's thy name slave?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Go look. At one end.
'Tis Harpax voice.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Harpax, go drag the caitiff to my foot,
That I may stamp upon him.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fool, thou liest. At tother end.
He's yonder now my lord.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Watch thou that end
Whilst I make good this.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha. At the middle.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: He's at barleybreak, and the last couple are now in hell,
Search for him, all this ground methink is bloody,
And paved with thousands of those christians' eyes
Whom I have tortured, and they stare upon me;
What was this apparition? sure it had
A shape angelical; mine eyes (Though dazzled
And daunted at first sight) tell me, it wore
A pair of glorious wings, yea they were wings,
And hence he flew; 'tis vanished, Jupiter
For all my sacrifices done to him
Never once gave me smile: how can stone smile,Music.
Or wooden image laugh? ha! I remember
Such music gave a welcome to my ear,
When the fair youth came to me: 'tis in the air,
Or from some better place, a power divine,
through my dark ignorance on my soul does shine,
And makes me see a conscience all stained o'er,
Nay drowned and damned for ever in Christian gore.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. Within.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Again, what dainty relish on my tongue
This fruit hath left, some angel hath me fed,
If so toothful, I will be banqueted.Eats another.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Hold.
sp.stage: Enter Harpax in a fearful shape, fire flashing out of the study.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not for Caesar.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: But for me thou shalt.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Thou art no twin to him that
Last was here.
You powers whom my soul bids me reverence
Guard me: what art thou?

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I'm thy master.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Mine.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: And thou my everlasting slave; that Harpax,
Who hand in hand hath led thee to thy hell
Am I.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Avant.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: I will not, cast thou down
That basket with the things in't, and fetch up
What thou hast swallowed, and then take a drink
Which I shall give thee, and I'm gone.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: My fruit!
Does this offend thee? see

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Spit it to'th earth,
And tread upon it, or I'll piecemeal tear thee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Art thou with this affrighted? see, hears more. Flowers.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Fling them away, I'll take thee else and hang thee
In a contorted chain of icicles
I'th frigid zone: down with them.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: At the bottom,
One thing I found not yet, see. A cross of flowers.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: O, I'm tortured.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Can this do't? hence thou fiend infernal hence.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Clasp Jupiter's image, and away with that.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: At thee I'll fling that Jupiter, for methinks
I serve a better master, he now checks me
For murdering my two daughters, put on by thee,
By thy damned rhetoric did I hunt the life
Of Dorothea, the holy virgin martyr,
She is not angry with the axe nor me,
But sends these presents to me, and its 〈◊〉
O'er world to find her, and from her white hand
To beg a forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: No, I'll bind thee here.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I set up a strength above thine: this small weapon methinks is armour hard enough.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Keep from me. Sinkes a little.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Art posting to thy centre? down hellhound, down,
Me hast thou lost; that arm which hurls thee hence
Save me, and set me up the strong defence
In the fair christians' quarrel.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Exit thy foot there,
Nor be thou shaken with a Caesar's voice,
Though thousand deaths were in it: and I then
Will bring thee to a river that shall wash
Thy bloody hands clean, and more white than snow,
And to that garden where these blessed things grow,
And to that martyred virgin, who hath sent
That heavenly token to thee; spread this brave wing
And serve then Caesar, a far greater King.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It is, it is some angel, vanished again!
O come back ravishing boy, bright messenger,
Thou hast (By these mine eyes fixed on thy beauty)
Illumined all my soul, now look I back
On my black tyrannies, which as they did.
Out dare the bloodiest, thou blessed spirit that leads me,
Teach me what I must do, and to do well,
That my last act, the best may parallel.

sp.stage: Enter Dioclesian, Maximinus, Epire, Pontus, Macedon, meeting Artemia, attendants.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Glory and conquest still attend upon
triumphant Caesar.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Let thy wish fair daughter
Be equally divided, and hereafter
Learn thou to know and reverence Maximinus,
Whose power with mine united makes one Caesar.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: But that I fear't would be held flattery,
The bonds considered in which we stand tide
As love, and empire, I should say till now
I ne'er had seen a lady I thought worthy
To be my mistress.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Sir, you show yourself
Both courtier and soldier, but take heed,
Take heed my lord, though my dull pointed beauty
Stained by a harsh refusal in my servant
Cannot dart forth such beams as may inflame you,
You may encounter such a powerful one,
That with a pleasing heat will thaw your heart
Though bound in ribs of ice, love still is love,
His bow and arrows are the same, great Julius
That to his successors left the name of Caesar
Whom war could never tame, that with dry eyes
Beheld the large plains of Pharsalia, covered
With the dead carcases of senators
And citizens of Rome, when the world knew
No other lord but him, struck deep in years to,
And men grey haired forget the lusts of youth:
After all this, meeting fair Cleopatra,
A suppliant to the magic of her eye,
Even in his pride of conquest took him captive,
Nor are you more secure.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Were you deformed
(But by the gods you are most excellent)
Your gravity and discretion would o'ercome me,
And I should be more proud in being a prisoner
To your fair virtues, then of all the honours,
Wealth, title, empire, that my sword hath purchased

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: This meets my wishes, welcome it Artemia
With outstretched arms, and study to forget
that Antoninus ever was thy fate
Reserved thee for this better choice, embrace it.

sp.speaker: Ep.
sp.l: This happy match brings new nerves to give strength
To our continued league.

sp.speaker: Mace.
sp.l: Hymen himself
Will bless this marriage which we will solemnize
In the presence of these Kings.

sp.speaker: Pon.
sp.l: Who rest most happy
To be eyewitnesses of a match that brings
Peace to the empire.

sp.speaker: Diocles.
sp.l: We much thank your loves,
But where's Sapritius our governor,
And our most zealous Provost good Theophilus?
If ever prince were blessed in a true servant,
Or could the gods be debtors to a man,
Both they and we stand far engaged to cherish
His piety and service.

sp.speaker: Artem.
sp.l: Sir the governor
Brooks sadly his son's loss although he turned
Apostata in death, but bold Theophilus
Who for the same cause in my presence sealed
His holy anger on his daughter's hearts.
Having with tortures first tried to convert her,
Dragged the bewitching Christian to the scaffold,
And saw her lose her head.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: He is all worthy,
And from his own mouth I would gladly hear
The manner how she suffered.

sp.speaker: Arte.
sp.l: 'Twill be delivered
With such contempt and scorn, I know his nature
That rather 'twill beget your highness' laughter
Then the least pity.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: To that end I would hear it.

sp.speaker: Arte.
sp.l: He comes, with him the governor.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: O Sapritius,
I am to chide you for your tenderness,
But yet remembering that you are a father,
I will forget it, good Theophilus
He speak with you anon: nearer your care, to Sapritius.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: By Antoninus' soul I do conjure you,
And though not for religion, for his friendship,
Without demanding what's the cause that moves me,
Receive my signet, by the power of this
Go to my prisons, and release all christian
That are in fetters there by my command.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: But what shall follow?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: Haste then to the port,
You there shall find two tall ships ready rigged,
In which embark the poor distressed souls
And bear them from the reach of tyranny,
Inquire not whither you are bound, the deity
That they adore will give you prosperous winds,
And make your voyage such, and largely pay for
Your hazard, and your travail: leave me here
There is a scene that I must act alone.
Haste good Macrinus, and the great God guide you.

sp.speaker: Mac.
sp.l: I'll undertake't, there's some thing prompts me to it
'Tis to save innocent blood, a saintlike act,
And to be merciful has never been
By mortal men themselves esteemed a sin.

sp.speaker: Dioc.
sp.l: You know your charge.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: And will with care observe it.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: For I profess he is not Caesar's friend
That sheds a tear for any torture that
A Christians suffers. Welcome my best servant
My careful, zealous Provost, thou hast toiled
To satisfy my will though in extremes,
I love thee for't, thou art firm rock, no changeling:
Prithee deliver, and for my sake do it
Without excess of bitterness or seosses
Before my brother and these Kings, how took
The christian her death.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: And such a presence
Though every private head in this large room
Were circled round with an imperial crown,
Her story will deserve, it is so full
Of excellency and wonder.

sp.speaker: Diocle.
sp.l: Ha! how's this?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: O mark it therefore, and with that attention,
As you would hear an embassy from heaven
By a winged legate, for the truth delivered,
Both how and what this blessed virgin suffered:
And Dorothea but hereafter named,
You will rise up with reverence, and no more
As things un worthy of your thoughts, remember
What the canonised Spartan ladies were
Which lying Greece so boasts of, your own matrons
Your Roman dames whose figures you yet keep
As holy relics in her historic
Will find a second urn. Gracchus, Cornelia,
Paulina that in death desired to follow
Her husband Seneca, nor Brutus Portia
That swallowed burning coals to overtake him,
Though all their several worths were given to one
With this is to be mentioned.

sp.speaker: Maximinus.
sp.l: Is he mad?

sp.speaker: Diocl.
sp.l: Why they did die Theophilus, and boldly.
This did no more.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: They out of desperation
Are for vain glory of an aftername
Parted with life. This had not mutinous sons
As the rash Gracchi were, nor was this saint
A doting mother as Cornelia was:
This lost no husband in whose overthrow
Her wealth and honour sunk, no fear of want
Did make her being tedious, but aiming
At an immortal crown, and in his cause
Who only can bestow it; who sent down
Legions of ministering angels to bear up
Her spotless soul to heaven; who entertained it
With choice celestial music, equal to
To the motion of the spheres, she uncompelled
Changed this life for a better. My lord Sapritius
You were present at her death, did you ere here
Such ravishing sounds?

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: Yet you said then it was witchcraft,
And devilish illusions.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: I then hard it
With sinful cares, and belched out blasphemous words
Against his deity, which then I knew not,
Nor did believe in him.

sp.speaker: Diocl.
sp.l: Why dost thou now? or dar'st thou in our hearing?

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: Were my voice
As loud as is his thunder, to be heard
Through all the world, all potentates on earth
Ready to burst with rage should they but hear it,
Though hell to aid their malice lent her furies
Yet I would speak, and speak again, and boldly,
I am a christian, and the powers you worship
But dreams of fools and madmen.

sp.speaker: Maximums.
sp.l: Lay hands on him.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Thou twice a child (For doting age so makes thee)
Thou could it not else thy pilgrimage of life,
Being almost passed through in the last moment,
Destroy whate'er thou hast done good or great,
Thy youth did promise much, and grown a man
Thou madest it good, and with increase of years
Thy actions still bettered as the sun
Thou did rise gloriously, kepst a constant course
In all thy journey, and now in the evening
When thou shouldst pass with honour to thy rest,
Wilt thou fall like a meteor?

sp.speaker: Sapritius.
sp.l: Yet confess
That thou art mad, and that thy tongue and heart
Had no agreement.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: Do, no way is left else
To save thy life Theophilus.

sp.speaker: Diocl.
sp.l: But refule it
Destruction as horrid and as sudden
Shall fall upon thee, as if hell stood open
And thou wert sinking thither.

sp.speaker: Theoph.
sp.l: Hear me yet
Here for my service past.

sp.speaker: Artem.
sp.l: What will he say?

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: At ever I deserved your favour hear me,
And grant one boon, 'tis not for life I sue for,
Nor is it fit that I that ne'er knew pity
To any christian, being one myself
Should look for any: no, I rather beg
The utmost of your cruelty; I stand
Accountable for thousand Christians deaths,
And were it possible that I could die
A day for every one, then live again
To be again tormented, t were to me
An easy penance, and I should pass through
A gentle cleansing fire, but that denied me,
It being beyond the strength of feeble nature,
My suit is you would have no pity on me.
In mine own house there are a thousand engine
Of studied cruelty, which I did prepare
For miserable Christians, let me seel
As the Sicilian did his brazen bull,
The horridst you can find, and I will say
In death that you are merciful.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.l: Despair not
In this thou shalt prevail, go fetch 'em hither,Some go for the racks.
Death shall put on a thousand shapes at once
And so appear before thee, racks, and whips,
Thy flesh with burning pincer torn, shall feed
The fire that heats them, and what's wanting to
The torture of thy body, I'll supply
In punishing thy mind: fetch all the Christians
That are in hold, and here before his face
Cut 'em in pieces.

sp.speaker: Theo.
sp.l: 'Tis not in thy power,
It was the first good deed I ever did,
They are removed out of thy reach, howe'er
I was determined for my sins to die,
I first took order for their liberty,
And still I dare thy worst.

sp.speaker: Diocle.
sp.l: Bind him I say,
make every artery and sinew crack,
The slave that makes him give the loudest shriek
Shall have ten thousand drachmas, wretch I'll force thee
To curse the power thou worshippest.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Never, never,
No breath of mine shall ever be spent on him,They torment him.
But what shall speak his majesty or mercy:
I am honoured in my sufferings, weak tormentors
More tortures, more: alas you are unskilful,
For heaven's sake more; my breast is yet untorn:
Here purchase the reward that was propounded,
The irons cool, here are arms yet and thighs,
Spare no part of me.

sp.speaker: Max.
sp.l: He endures beyond
The sufferance of a man.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: No sigh nor groan
To witness he has feeling.

sp.speaker: Dio.
sp.l: Harder villains.

sp.speaker: Har.
sp.l: Unless that he blaspheme he's lost for ever,
If torments ever could bring forth despair,
Let these compel him to it. o me
My ancient enemies again,Falls down.

sp.stage: Enter Darothea in a white robe, crowns upon her robe, a crown upon her head, lead in by the angel. Antoninus, Caliste and Christeta following all in white, but less glorious, the angel with a crown for him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Most glorious vision,
Did ere so hard a bed yield man a dream
So heavenly as this? I am confirmed,
Confirmed you blessed spirits, and make haste
To take that crown of immortality
You offer to me; death till this blessed minute
I never thought thee slow paced, nor could I
Hasten thee now for any pain I suffer,
But that thou kepst me from a glorious wreath
Which through this stormy way I would creep to,
and humbly kneeling with humility wear it.
O now I feel thee, blessed spirits I come
And witness for me, all these wounds and scars,
I die a soldier in the Christian wars.Dies.

sp.speaker: Sap.
sp.l: I have seen thousands tortured, but ne'er yet
A constancy like this.

sp.speaker: Harpax.
sp.l: I am twice damned.

sp.speaker: Aug.
sp.l: Haste to thy place appointed cursed fiend,
In spite of hell this soldier's not thy prey,
'Tis I have won, thou that hast lost the day.
sp.stage: Exit Angele the devil sinks with lightning.

sp.speaker: Die.
sp.l: I think the centre of the earth be cracks,
Yet I still stand unmoved, and will go on,
The persecution that is here begun,
Through all the world with violence shall run.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
